Award.AwardTitle: OPUS-A Synthesis of Anthurium and Philodendron (Araceae) for Neotropical America
Award.AbstractNarration:
The American tropical regions, the Neotropics, have high rates of plant speciation. In some plant families such as the Araceae, the aroid or Philodendron family, this has led to unusually high rates of species richness and local rarity. Thus the presence of Araceae species is a major indicator of the value of proposed conservation parks and natural reserves throughout the tropics. This project will provide detailed taxonomic descriptions of an estimated 2700 species of Anthurium and Philodendron, the two largest genera in the Araceae, this constitutes about 45% of the entire family. The family is preeminent in horticulture where the family rates first in potted plant sales and is renowned for indoor landscaping due to the resilient growth in low light conditions. Since plants are easily brought into cultivation and are highly ornamental, growers all over the world will benefit from the taxonomic revision, which includes morphological and ecological descriptions, of the Araceae. The availability of so many species also insures that the family will remain an important tool in teaching biology, especially owing to the many interesting and unique features the plants exhibit such as the production of heat and a wide array of flower types and pollination systems.

The goal of the project is to synthesize in a comprehensive, systematic-phylogenetic manner the 47 years of research at the Missouri Botanical Garden on Neotropical Anthurium and Philodendron. The work entails includes floristic accounts of most areas in the Neotropics, nine major revisions, 200 publications, over 2400 taxonomic novelties, and many unpublished systematic and floristic treatments. Herbarium collections will be used to identify new and to refine existing species definitions in Araceae. The taxonomic data for all species will be entered into the Lucid program, a user friendly multi-entry computerized plant identification key. The key's database will store morphological and ecological trait information which is used to help people identify plant specimens and the data can be used in analyses. The Lucid keys will be available online to the plant sciences, horticultural community and the general public worldwide on at least two websites and will enable users to make determinations of these horticulturally important groups. This precise information coupled with images of all species will be assembled on the website of the Missouri Botanical Garden as a part of Tropicos, currently one of the most heavily used plant databases in the world. At the same time floristic and revisionary accounts of most of the Neotropical Araceae will be made available online on the Missouri Botanical Garden's website. An important aspect of the project will be the training of 20 botanists from Latin America who are interested in Araceae and who will learn a variety of new approaches to aroid taxonomy including how to construct Lucid keys and other tools that will enable them to continue research with Araceae and to be more efficient in conducting research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
OPUS: A Synthesis of Anthurium and Philodendron (Araceae) for Neotropical America

Thomas B. Croat, Missouri Botanical Garden

 

My career at the Missouri Botanical Garden has spanned the last fifty years. During the past three years, with support from an OPUS Grant from the National Science Foundation, I have worked toward the goal of summarizing a lifelong study of the aroid family (Araceae), also commonly known as the Philodendron or Jack-in-the-Pulpit Family. Curiously, while most people recognize the family from some of its more conspicuous elements: ?Peace Lily? (Spathiphyllum), ?Skunk Cabbage?, Philodendron, Monstera, ?Pothos?, Syngonium or even Anthurium, few recognize the family name or even the common name, aroid. Yet a simple walk through public places usually provides many opportunities to see living collections of these plants. No other family of its size or complexity (currently with 144 known genera and 3645 accepted species) has such a high percentage of its species still new to science. It is not uncommon for up to half of all the species in a poorly collected habitat to represent new species.  My comparisons of now well-known areas with poorly known areas indicates that there are thousands more species still undiscovered.

My OPUS study had several goals but the main purpose was to make available to the scientific world and to future workers an analysis of where research now stands, to provide an accounting of the species that are known to exist, to provide accurate and detailed descriptions and images of them as well as to make this information available to the public. Toward that end, I conducted a survey of all the world?s major herbaria (70 in all). I identified all of the species I knew, photographed and later permanently cataloged into a photographic database all as yet undetermined plants. Moreover, we assembled descriptions of all of the species of Anthurium and Philodendron, the two largest genera in the family together constituting about 40% of the species in the family. 

Another main goal of the OPUS study was to provide a means to identify the known species. Toward that end, we entered the data for all the described species of Anthurium and Philodendron into Lucid Keys which provide the possibility of identifying a plant by winnowing out species not sharing features with it. The key is illustrated so that even technical characters are easily understood and the key can thus be operated by almost anyone interested in natural history.

In conjunction with the identification keys we generated archives of easily accessible images and detailed descriptions of all species so that any unfamiliar name could quickly be seen for comparative purposes. The latter tool we call the ?Determination Tool? even though for practical reasons it is intended that it be used with the Lucid Keys to evaluate the series of names of possible species remaining from an identification effort.

The Araceae Research Group at the Missouri Botanical Garden constitutes a mostly voluntary group of 25 semi-professionals who help with every aspect of this research. This work has involved digitizing many previously published work, digitizing and naming thousands of images making them quickly available on any topic or name. Always the data is collections oriented with a single number representing dried herbarium specimens, images of live plants, images of type specimens (the official specimen which guarantees standard identification) and images of other associated collections of living plants in the field and cultivated plants in the greenhouses. All of this information is available worldwide through the use of TROPICOS, the Missouri Botanical Garden?s plant database.

Since I am nearing the end of my career, I have worked to ensure that this still unfinished work is carried on. During the first two years of my OPUS, grant I spent time visiting and training other aroid researchers, particularly in Central and South America where most current workers reside and where nearly all of the most poorly known groups of aroids occur. Copies of the Lucid Keys, Determination Tool and general literature were distributed, classes were presented on the operation of Lucid Keys and information was provided on how to acquire a free copy of the Lucid Program. In the second year, I helped to organize the first International Aroid Conference in Latin America.  Researchers from all over Latin America came to exchange ideas with others from North America, Europe and Asia. This meeting helped to ensure that professional collaborations were developed that will persist.

        One final concern is the knowledge that thousands more species remain uncollected in large and species-rich countries like Colombia. Owing to misguided environmental or political concerns, our efforts to find them are diminishing each year. Without a greater effort to explore these vast tracts of poorly known areas, many species will go extinct before we ever get to know them.
